raw_text:
Baghdad Blogger on big screen
 
 A film based on the internet musings of the "Baghdad Blogger" has been shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival.
 
 The film has been directed by the man who calls himself Salam Pax, the author of the weblog about Iraqi life during and after the war. The movie version comes in the form of a series of shorts made by Pax on a hand-held camera. Baghdad Blogger is among a number of films about Iraq showcased at the Dutch festival, which runs until Sunday. Following the fascination with the writing of Salam Pax - not his real name - he began a regular column in The Guardian newspaper and was given a crash course in documentary film-making. For the film he travelled Iraq to document the changing landscape of the country and the problems it has faced since the invasion, speaking to ordinary Iraqis about their experiences. The festival will also see the screening of Underexposure, one of Iraq's first features to emerge since the toppling of Saddam Hussein.
 
 Director Oday Rasheed made the film on discarded 1980s Kodak film taken from the remains for the former Ministry of Culture building. It centres on the lives of families and strangers going about their everyday business as Baghdad is under siege. Rasheed said the title was refers to the isolation felt by Iraqis under Saddam's regime and the difficult time the country is now experiencing. "Saddam's regime was hell, but now I think the hell has doubled," Rasheed said. The festival was also due to screen murdered Dutch film-maker Theo Van Gogh's film about the treatment of woman under Islam, but it was withdrawn due to safety fears. Van Gogh was shot and stabbed in November 2004, following death threats he received about his film Submission.
llama3.2:1b:
A Baghdad Blogger film is shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival. 

The film was directed by Salam Pax, who wrote a weblog about Iraqi life before the war. 
Pax made shorts on a hand-held camera about Iraq after being given documentary filmmaking training.
The film documents families and strangers in Baghdad as it faces problems since the invasion.
Director Oday Rasheed shot the film using discarded 1980s Kodak film from the former Ministry of Culture building.
The title refers to isolation under Saddam's regime and current difficulties.
llama3.2:3b: A film based on Salam Pax's blog about Iraqi life has been shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival. Directed by Salam Pax, the movie features a series of shorts made on hand-held cameras documenting Iraq's changing landscape and ordinary people's experiences since the invasion. The festival also screens Underexposure, one of Iraq's first feature films, directed by Oday Rasheed, who used discarded 1980s film to depict life under siege in Baghdad.
gemma2:2b: A film based on the internet musings of "Baghdad Blogger," Salam Pax, has been shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival. The film, a series of shorts shot by Pax on a hand-held camera, documents the changes in Iraq since the invasion and interviews ordinary Iraqis about their experiences.  The director Oday Rasheed made his film from 1980s Kodak film found in the remains of a former Ministry of Culture building, focusing on everyday life under siege. Another film at the festival, Underexposure, focuses on the challenges Iraq faces after Saddam's regime and the difficulty of living today.  The festival also had to cancel a screening of a film by Dutch filmmaker Theo Van Gogh about women and Islam due to safety fears.

The film features a series of shorts made by the author Salam Pax, who uses documentary filmmaking techniques to document Iraq's changing landscape and problems since the invasion. It begins with a crash course in documentary film-making for Pax before he travels Iraq and speaks to ordinary people about their experiences. The festival will also screen an article from 1980s Kodak film taken from the remains of the former Ministry of Culture building, which is related to the conflict between Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi government.

The festival also showcases "Underexposure," one of Iraq's first films since the fall of Saddam Hussein, but which was withdrawn due to safety concerns after Theo Van Gogh's death.
qwen2.5:3b: A film based on Baghdad Blogger's internet musings has been shown at Rotterdam Film Festival. Directed by Salam Pax, a filmmaker who chronicled Iraqi life during war, the project includes shorts made with a handheld camera. Meanwhile, another film showcases Iraq's transition post-Saddam Hussein. The festival also screened Van Gogh's film criticizing Islam but withdrew it due to safety concerns following threats.

The festival will also see the film Underexposure, a first-person video experience by a filmmaker about a difficult time the country is now experiencing. The director made the film on a discarded 1980 Kodak camera from the remains of the former ministry building.".

The film based on the "Baghdad Blogger" blog directed by Oday Rasheed was shown at the Rotterdam Film Festival. It focuses on families and ordinary Iraqis in 2012 during the Siege of Hama, discussing their lives and challenges. The festival also screened Underexposure, Iraq's first feature since Saddam Hussein's regime.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Rotterdam Film Festival has showcased the internet musings of Salam Pax as a series of short films made by him on a hand-held camera. The film is among a number of documentaries about Iraq, with the focus being on the changing landscape since the invasion and the problems faced by the country since Saddam Hussein's reign. Directed by the man who goes by Salam Pax himself, Underexposure is one such feature-length work to emerge from the region since the Fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003. The film centers around the experiences of ordinary Iraqis during a time of political and socioeconomic upheaval. Baghdad Blogger, as Salam Pax is known on the internet, is one of several films screened at the festival, which also features the director's underground classic, Sadism & Ecstasy (Saddam's regime was hell, but now I think it has doubled).
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Rotterdam Film Festival will be screening a film based on the blog of an internet-based Iraqi writer called Baghdad Blogger. The movie features short films made by the man himself, Salam Pax, on handheld cameras. This Baghdad Blogger film is among a number of movies showcased at the Rotterdam Film Festival, which will be available for viewing until Sunday. Following his regular column in The Guardian newspaper, Baghdad Blogger was granted access to document the changing landscape of Iraq and its people's experiences since the invasion. The festival will also screen another film by Oday Rasheed, Underexposure, a first feature from 1980s Kodak film material. This movie centers on the lives of families and strangers who go about their daily business amidst the devastation caused by Saddam Hussein's regime. The title of the film is an allusion to the sense of isolation felt by Iraqis under these circumstances.

Director Oday Rasheed made his film using discarded film from a former Ministry of Culture building in Baghdad. It centers on the lives of families and strangers in the city, which is under siege. granite3.1-dense:2b:

The film is a series of shorts made on a handheld camera, reflecting Iraq's post-invasion challenges and the author's experiences documenting life in Baghdad. Pax later transitioned from writing to creating documentaries for The Guardian.

Meanwhile, another Iraqi film, "Underexposure," directed by Oday Rasheed, depicts everyday life in Baghdad under siege during Saddam Hussein's regime and the subsequent turmoil. Rasheed used discarded 1980s Kodak film to capture the story, emphasizing Iraqis' isolation and current hardships as "doubled hell."

The festival was also set to showcase Theo Van Gogh's controversial film about women's treatment under Islam, but it was withdrawn due to safety concerns following Van Gogh's murder in 2004.
